diseases: Aspartame can cause headaches and allergic reactions in some individuals. It's often considered safe in moderation
but some studies suggest a potential link to health issues.
Sucralose is generally recognized as safe
but some studies suggest it may alter gut bacteria and cause digestive issues.
Saccharin has been linked to bladder cancer in laboratory animals
but extensive studies show it is safe for human consumption in moderation.
Stevia is a natural sweetener and may have health benefits
including lowering blood sugar levels and having antioxidant properties.
Red 40 is associated with allergic reactions and hyperactivity in children
although the evidence is inconclusive.
Yellow 5 may cause allergic reactions in some people and has been linked to hyperactivity in children.
Blue 1 has been associated with allergic reactions and potential behavioral effects in children.
Sodium benzoate may produce benzene
a known carcinogen
when combined with vitamin C
and has been linked to hyperactivity in children.
Benzoates can cause allergic reactions in some individuals and have been associated with hyperactivity in children.
Potassium sorbate is generally recognized as safe but may cause skin irritation or allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
Sorbates are generally safe but can cause allergic reactions in some people.
Natural and artificial flavors can contain various compounds
some of which may trigger allergies or sensitivities.
High maltose corn syrup is a high-calorie sweetener that may contribute to obesity and metabolic disorders.
Interestified fats can impact cholesterol levels and may be linked to health issues
depending on their sources.
Some preservatives may cause allergic reactions or sensitivities
while others are considered safe.
Excessive sugar consumption can lead to obesity
diabetes
and heart disease.
High salt intake can lead to hypertension and increase the risk of heart disease.
Water is essential for life
but excessive consumption can lead to water intoxication.
Wheat can trigger gluten sensitivities or celiac disease in some individuals.
Milk is a good source of calcium and vitamin D but can cause lactose intolerance in some people.
Excessive consumption of vegetable oils
particularly those high in omega-6 fatty acids
may lead to inflammation.
Palm oil is high in saturated fats
which may increase cholesterol levels if consumed excessively.
Corn syrup is high in fructose and can contribute to obesity and metabolic syndrome.
Dextrose is a simple sugar that can spike blood sugar levels if consumed in excess.
Glucose is a primary energy source
but excessive intake can lead to health issues like obesity and diabetes.
Fructose can lead to insulin resistance and fatty liver disease when consumed in large amounts.
Citric acid is generally safe
but excessive consumption may cause digestive issues for some individuals.
Sodium bicarbonate can help with indigestion but excessive use may lead to metabolic alkalosis.
Xanthan gum is generally safe
but excessive consumption can cause digestive issues.
Soy lecithin is considered safe but may cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to soy.
Cocoa butter is high in fat but is generally healthy when consumed in moderation.
Cocoa solids contain antioxidants and may have heart health benefits but can also contain sugar in processed forms.
Skimmed milk powder is low in fat but provides essential nutrients
making it a healthy choice.
Whole milk powder contains fats that can contribute to overall calorie intake
impacting weight management.
Maltodextrin can spike blood sugar levels and should be consumed in moderation by those with diabetes.
Whey protein is a high-quality protein source
beneficial for muscle recovery but may cause digestive issues in lactose-intolerant individuals.
Gelatin is safe for most but can cause allergic reactions in some.
Corn starch is a high-calorie thickener and should be consumed in moderation.
Potato starch is a carbohydrate that can spike blood sugar levels and should be consumed in moderation.
Modified starches are used as thickeners but may contain additives that some individuals may want to avoid.
Rice flour is gluten-free but can spike blood sugar levels in excess.
Barley malt extract can contribute to overall calorie intake and should be consumed in moderation.
Natural flavorings can vary widely; their health impact depends on the source ingredients.
Artificial flavorings may have health risks depending on their chemical composition.
MSG is considered safe by regulatory agencies
but some individuals may experience sensitivity.
Soy protein isolate is a good protein source but can cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
Yeast extract can provide flavor but may contain high sodium levels.
Baking powder is generally safe but can contribute to sodium intake.
Excessive sodium chloride intake can lead to hypertension and cardiovascular issues.
Calcium carbonate is a common calcium supplement
generally safe in recommended amounts.
Caramel color may contain compounds that some individuals may wish to avoid.
Ascorbic acid
or vitamin C
is an antioxidant and is generally safe in recommended doses.
Vanilla extract is generally safe but may contain alcohol and added sugars.
Soybean oil is high in omega-6 fatty acids and should be consumed in moderation.
Hydrogenated oils may contain trans fats
which are linked to health issues.
Emulsifiers are generally safe but can cause digestive issues in sensitive individuals.
Antioxidants are beneficial for health
reducing oxidative stress and inflammation.
Sorbitol can cause digestive issues in large amounts but is used as a low-calorie sweetener.
Glycerin is generally safe but can cause gastrointestinal distress in high amounts.
Pectin is safe and may have health benefits
including lowering cholesterol levels.
Dextrin can spike blood sugar levels and should be consumed in moderation.
Lactic acid is safe and often used in fermentation and as a preservative.
Sodium nitrate can be harmful in high amounts
linked to certain health risks.
Sodium nitrite is used in cured meats and may be linked to certain health risks.
Calcium phosphate is safe and often used as a supplement.
Monoglycerides are generally safe and used as emulsifiers.
Diglycerides are generally safe and used as emulsifiers.
Enzymes are beneficial for digestion and various bodily functions.
Carboxymethyl cellulose is generally safe but may cause digestive issues in sensitive individuals.
Polysorbate 80 is generally safe
but some studies suggest potential effects on gut health.
Propylene glycol is considered safe in food but can cause irritation in high amounts.
High fructose corn syrup is linked to obesity and metabolic disorders when consumed in excess.
Sorbitan monostearate is generally safe as an emulsifier but may cause digestive issues.
Acacia gum is safe and may have health benefits
including aiding digestion.
Sodium metabisulfite can cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
Tapioca starch is safe but can spike blood sugar levels if consumed in excess.
Sunflower oil is generally healthy
but excessive intake of omega-6 fatty acids can lead to inflammation.
Olive oil is beneficial for heart health due to its monounsaturated fats and antioxidants.
Canola oil is low in saturated fat but may contain omega-6 fatty acids
which should be consumed in moderation.
Almond oil is healthy and contains healthy fats but should be consumed in moderation.
Flaxseed oil is high in omega-3 fatty acids and has health benefits when consumed in moderation.
Coconut oil is high in saturated fats
which should be consumed in moderation.
